verses.text: When the Philistines captured the ark of God, they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
verses.comment: Faithful to the Hebrew; no significant differences.

verses.text: The Philistines took the ark of God and brought it into the house of Dagon, and set it beside Dagon.
verses.comment: Dagon is the Philistine god. 'House' refers to a temple.

verses.text: When the people of Ashdod rose early the next day, behold, Dagon had fallen on his face to the ground before the ark of the LORD. So they took Dagon and set him back in his place.
verses.comment: The word 'behold' translates Hebrew 'hinneh', an exclamation.

verses.text: But when they rose early the next morning, behold, Dagon had fallen on his face to the ground before the ark of the LORD. The head of Dagon and both the palms of his hands were cut off on the threshold; only the trunk of Dagon was left to him.
verses.comment: Literally 'only Dagon was left to him' — meaning only the body remained.

verses.text: Therefore, neither the priests of Dagon nor anyone who enters Dagon’s house steps on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod to this day.
verses.comment: Phrase 'to this day' reflects the Hebrew's timeframe from the author's perspective.

verses.text: But the hand of the LORD was heavy against the people of Ashdod, and he devastated them and struck them with tumors, both Ashdod and its territory.
verses.comment: Tumors (Hebrew: tehorim). Some translations render as 'hemorrhoids,' but 'tumors' is accurate.

verses.text: And when the men of Ashdod saw how things were, they said, 'The ark of the God of Israel must not stay with us, for his hand is hard against us and against Dagon our god.'
verses.comment: Faithful rendering; 'his hand' refers to God's power.

verses.text: So they sent and gathered all the lords of the Philistines and said, 'What shall we do with the ark of the God of Israel?' They answered, 'Let the ark of the God of Israel be brought around to Gath.' So they brought the ark of the God of Israel there.
verses.comment: ‘Lords’ translates Hebrew 'seranim,' meaning rulers of the Philistines.

verses.text: But after they brought it around, the hand of the LORD was against the city, causing a very great panic, and he struck the people of the city, both small and great, and tumors broke out on them.
verses.comment: 'Great panic' is literal; both high and low suffered.

verses.text: So they sent the ark of God to Ekron. But as soon as the ark of God came to Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, saying, 'They have brought around to us the ark of the God of Israel to kill us and our people.'
verses.comment: Rendering follows the sequence and the outcry of the Ekronites.

verses.text: They sent therefore and gathered together all the lords of the Philistines and said, 'Send away the ark of the God of Israel, and let it return to its own place, so that it does not kill us and our people.' For there was a deadly panic throughout the whole city. The hand of God was very heavy there.
verses.comment: Maintains the Hebrew structure; 'deadly panic' as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: The men who did not die were struck with tumors, and the cry of the city went up to heaven.
verses.comment: 'Cry went up to heaven' is Hebrew idiom for intense suffering and prayer. 'Tumors' as in verse 6.
